mainBoard.flavorText: Once he'd worked out which end of the thing was sharp, he was promoted to guard duty.
mainBoard.name: Goblin Piker

mainBoard.flavorText: The goblin word for "flying" is more accurately translated as "falling slowly."
mainBoard.name: Goblin Sky Raider
mainBoard.text: Flying (This creature can't be blocked except by creatures with flying or reach.)

mainBoard.flavorText: "If the whole world burns, I'll never grow cold."
mainBoard.name: Cinder Pyromancer
mainBoard.text:
{T}: This creature deals 1 damage to target player or planeswalker.
Whenever you cast a red spell, you may untap this creature.

mainBoard.flavorText: Fortunately, hill giants have large blind spots in which a human can easily hide. Unfortunately, these blind spots are beneath the bottoms of their feet.
mainBoard.name: Hill Giant

mainBoard.flavorText:
"A flash of the lightning, a break of the wave,
He passes from life to his rest in the grave."
—William Knox, "Mortality"
mainBoard.name: Lightning Elemental
mainBoard.text: Haste (This creature can attack and {T} as soon as it comes under your control.)

mainBoard.flavorText: Earth elementals have the eternal strength of stone and the endurance of mountains. Primordially connected to the land they inhabit, they take a long-term view of things, scorning the impetuous haste of short-lived mortal creatures.
mainBoard.name: Earth Elemental

mainBoard.flavorText: Boggarts divide the world into two categories: things you can eat, and things you have to chase down and pummel before you can eat.
mainBoard.name: Bloodmark Mentor
mainBoard.text: Red creatures you control have first strike.

mainBoard.flavorText: "What am I looking at? Ashes, dead man."
mainBoard.name: Prodigal Pyromancer
mainBoard.text: {T}: This creature deals 1 damage to any target.

mainBoard.flavorText: In times when freedom seems lost, great souls arise to reclaim it.
mainBoard.name: Kamahl, Pit Fighter

rulings.text: The Legend rule only applies to two legendary permanents with identical names. If the names are different, even if they depict the same character, the rule does not apply.

mainBoard.text:
Haste (This creature can attack and {T} as soon as it comes under your control.)
{T}: Kamahl deals 3 damage to any target.

mainBoard.flavorText: The undisputed master of the mountains of Shiv.
mainBoard.name: Shivan Dragon
mainBoard.text:
Flying
{R}: This creature gets +1/+0 until end of turn.

mainBoard.name: Blaze
mainBoard.text: Blaze deals X damage to any target.

mainBoard.flavorText:
"Rage courses in every heart, yearning to betray its rational prison."
—Sarkhan Vol
mainBoard.name: Act of Treason

rulings.text: Act of Treason can target any creature, even one that's untapped or one you already control.
Gaining control of a creature doesn't cause you to gain control of any Auras or Equipment attached to it.

mainBoard.text: Gain control of target creature until end of turn. Untap that creature. It gains haste until end of turn. (It can attack and {T} this turn.)

mainBoard.flavorText: For Sarkhan Vol, the dragon is the purest expression of life's savage splendor.
mainBoard.name: Banefire

rulings.text: Banefire can be targeted by spells that try to counter it regardless of what the value of X is. If X is 5 or more, those spells will still resolve, but the part of their effect that would counter Banefire won’t do anything. Any other effects those spells have will work as normal.
If its target is illegal by the time Banefire tries to resolve, the spell isn’t countered, but it doesn’t resolve. The target won’t be dealt damage.

To determine whether it can be countered and its damage can be prevented, Banefire checks the number you chose for X, not the amount of mana you actually spent or the amount of damage it will actually deal.

mainBoard.text:
Banefire deals X damage to any target.
If X is 5 or more, this spell can't be countered and the damage can't be prevented.

mainBoard.flavorText:
"Yes, I think 'toast' is an appropriate description."
—Jaya Ballard, task mage
mainBoard.name: Incinerate

rulings.text: Regeneration abilities that would affect that creature can still be activated; they just won’t do anything. The creature can’t be regenerated for any reason, even if an effect other than Incinerate would deal lethal damage to it or otherwise destroy it.

mainBoard.text: Incinerate deals 3 damage to any target. A creature dealt damage this way can't be regenerated this turn.

mainBoard.flavorText:
"Once I saw a goblin shouting at a thunderstorm. He lost the argument pretty quickly."
—Wandering mage
mainBoard.name: Shock
mainBoard.text: Shock deals 2 damage to any target.

mainBoard.flavorText: The barbarians call it "touching the soul of the dragon."
mainBoard.name: Enrage
mainBoard.text: Target creature gets +X/+0 until end of turn.

mainBoard.flavorText: Though no longer attached to the hand, it still holds its adversary in its grasp.
mainBoard.name: Dragon's Claw

rulings.text: If a player casts a red spell, Dragon’s Claw’s ability triggers and is put on the stack on top of that spell. Dragon’s Claw’s ability will resolve (causing you to gain 1 life) before the spell does.
The ability triggers whenever any player, not just you, casts a red spell.

mainBoard.text: Whenever a player casts a red spell, you may gain 1 life.

mainBoard.flavorText: Vengeance is a dish best served twice.
mainBoard.name: Rage Reflection

rulings.text: If a creature loses double strike after assigning damage in the first strike combat damage step (due to Rage Reflection leaving the battlefield, for example), that creature won't assign damage in the normal combat damage step.

mainBoard.text: Creatures you control have double strike.

mainBoard.flavorText: The furnace awaits the next master who would stoke the fires of apocalypse.
mainBoard.name: Furnace of Rath

rulings.text: If a spell or ability damages multiple things, divide up the damage before applying this effect. This means you can’t normally end up with an odd amount of damage on something.
If you have two of these on the battlefield, the damage is multiplied by 4.
The multiplied damage counts in all ways as if it came from the original source. Furnace of Rath is not the source.
The trample rules cause damage to be divided before it is doubled.

If multiple effects modify how damage will be dealt, the player who would be dealt damage or the controller of the creature that would be dealt damage chooses the order to apply the effects. For example, Mending Hands says, “Prevent the next 4 damage that would be dealt to any target this turn.” Suppose a spell would deal 5 damage to a player who has cast Mending Hands targeting themselves. That player can either (a) prevent 4 damage first and then let Furnace of Rath double the remaining 1 damage, taking 2 damage, or (b) double the damage to 10 and then prevent 4 damage, taking 6 damage.

mainBoard.text: If a source would deal damage to a permanent or player, it deals double that damage to that permanent or player instead.
